What is Crucible.name: What is Crucible
What is Crucible.text:
Crucible is an innovative and modern role-playing game (RPG) system built exclusively for Foundry Virtual Tabletop as a digital platform.

Crucible is designed from the ground up to leverage the unique capabilities of Foundry Virtual Tabletop to create exciting and fast-paced gameplay that allow gamemasters and players to focus on what matters most: telling a compelling story.

At the heart of Crucible is meaningful and empowering character advancement through a class-less system with multiple pillars of character progression. The system’s dice mechanics allow for crunchy and tactically rich encounters featuring combat, exploration, or social challenges.

Crucible is both a role-playing game and a software engine. The game system offers a deep level of mechanical sophistication, but its rules are entirely encoded to be applied with consistency and automation. The system is built intentionally to eliminate the cumbersome bookkeeping that is prevalent in high-crunch pen-and-paper systems.

Development Status

Crucible is now available for its Alpha Playtest which provides the community with a first look at the system, design pillars, and intended direction. The system is moderately functional, but still early in development. All areas of the system are works-in-progress and some areas are not yet developed at all. This playtest offers a chance for us to collect early feedback and share our work with the community. Please approach it with an open mind and an understanding that what you are seeing is still a long way from a finished product.

Blocks like this one in the system documentation highlight areas of the system that still require substantial development. These are intended to make you aware of areas that are intentionally unfinished at this time.

Development of Crucible is two-pronged with an equal focus on developing the system mechanics of the roleplaying game and the software implementation of those mechanics simultaneously. As the game mechanics evolve, new developments of the game system will enable those features for use in testing. The playtest process allows us to solicit and benefit from feedback that helps us iterate on the game rules and the user experience in Foundry Virtual Tabletop. We anticipate hosting multiple rounds of feedback, each focusing on a different aspect of the game experience.

Playtest One

The first playtest, @UUID[Compendium.crucible.playtest.Adventure.F8AILycmdj2kuOVa]{Playtest 1 - The Ring of Valor}, is focused on @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6]{Character Creation} and @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.QhZgmBrdLAGwYy5c]{Combat Encounters}. This playtest provides an abbreviated introduction to the Crucible game system, covering character creation, dice mechanics, combat encounters, and level advancement. The playtest begins at level 1 and advances characters through level 6 allowing them to evolve and advance their character between each challenge of the test.

Please note that the rules and mechanics featured in this playtest are not final. Most talents, skills, and rules will be further refined during later phases of development.

Ember

There is far more Crucible content available as part of our original setting and epic adventure Ember, which is now in Kickstarter Beta testing phase. Ember is available for pre-order, and will contain an immense campaign for Crucible spanning several years of gameplay taking your party from character level 1 to 12 (or beyond).

System Cornerstones.name: System Cornerstones
System Cornerstones.text:
Crucible is built with the following cornerstones and design principles in mind.

Consequential Character Progression

A primary goal for Crucible is to provide systems for meaningful, exciting, and impactful character progression. Creating and advancing a character in Crucible should be enjoyable and impactful as you gain access to new capabilities that tangibly evolve your playstyle and character persona.

Strategic Grid-Based Combat

Game mechanics in Crucible are designed for application to encounter or area maps with a structured grid which defines distances and positions of characters to create tactical choices about movement during combat. Movement actions and costs, engagement, flanking, cover, area-of-effect abilities, and more are all ways to add tactical nuance and dynamism to combat.

Consistently Automated Mechanics

A key goal for Crucible is to design and implement mechanics which are seamlessly automated or theoretically capable of seamless automation. We don't want automation that distracts from gameplay with the need for bookkeeping - but we also want the underlying game mechanics which are automated to be understandable to players at the table. We don't want mechanics which are inscrutable simply because we have a layer of automation in front of them. In Crucible you will find game mechanics which are elegantly and intuitively designed, but our approach to full automation of those mechanics means you can stay focused on the fun of roleplaying.

Bring Your Own Story

Crucible is optimized and designed with extended-form narrative in mind. While it can be used for one-shot adventures, the system's mechanics are intended to play out over months or years of game sessions.

Crucible provides relatively little rule-based guidance around narrative, personal character story, or the development of intrapersonal relationships - deliberately leaving these narrative pillars for the Game Master and players to explore using whatever setting or storytelling style they most prefer.

Crucible intentionally does not define a canonical setting. The system provides Gamemasters with tools to apply the system to a variety of settings. As a general rule of thumb, Crucible will work best in a gritty fantasy setting but it can be adapted for other genres and tones.

Ease of Powerful Use

Crucible is designed to be a system which is easy to learn and easy to use. Gamemasters should feel empowered to tell the stories they want to tell, and players to play the characters they want to play. We want game mechanics in Crucible to be crunchy and strategic while being presented to players in a way that is intuitive and fun to engage with.

Dice So Nice

Dice Mechanics.name: Dice Mechanics
Dice Mechanics.text:
Crucible uses the standard set of role-playing game dice; relying upon 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 20-sided dice for various rolls. These dice are referred to as d4, d6, d8, d10, and d12, where a number that precedes the die type represents the quantity of that die to roll, for example 4d6 provides instruction to roll four six-sided dice.

Crucible is designed specifically for Foundry Virtual Tabletop, but its dice mechanics are possible to play outside of a digital environment, albeit with a fairly high level of bookkeeping required.

When your character performs heroic actions within the world, whether they be feats of martial prowess or clever social maneuvers, the outcomes of the attempted action are discovered by rolling dice.

Standard Check

The standard approach towards determining the outcome of a dice check in Crucible uses a dice pool comprised of three dice, typically 3d8, which are added together. The exact dice used in the pool are modified depending on the Boons or Banes which apply to the roll. Added to the result of these three dice are Ability, Skill, and Enchantment bonuses which further increase the value of the result. This type of dice roll is referred to as a Standard Check.

Standard Check

=

3d8[Boons,Banes] + Ability Bonus + Skill Bonus + Enchantment Bonus

Boons and Banes.name: Boons and Banes
Boons and Banes.text:
A goblin desperately thrusts at an armored human with its damaged, dull blade. An enchanter wishes to haggle with a merchant she has magically charmed. A soldier swings his hammer at the head of a dazed, concussed ogre. When performing a check, a character may find some favorable circumstances shift the odds in their favor. Other disadvantageous circumstances will hinder a character's odds of success.

Circumstances which apply beneficial or detrimental forces upon the likelihood of a check being successful are represented as Boons and Banes, respectively. The number of boons and banes to be applied to a roll are determined before a roll is made, as they directly affect the composition of the dice pool that is used. A single dice pool roll can have no more than 6 boons and 6 banes affecting it.

Boons

Each Boon applied to the check increments the denomination of the first die in the pool by +2, to a maximum of d12. If a die is already a d12 due to other boons, the increase is applied to the next die in the pool. In practical terms, boons upgrade dice making them bigger and more effective.

Banes

Each Bane applied to the check decrements the denomination of the last die in the pool by -2, to a minimum of d4. If a die is already a d4 due to other banes, the decrease is applied to the next die in the pool. In practical terms, banes downgrade dice making them smaller and less effective.

Mitigating Circumstances

Because boons and banes start at opposite ends of the dice pool, they can both affect changes to the same roll. For example, a check made with with 2 Boons and 2 Banes would result in a dice pool of 1d12 + 1d8 + 1d4. If more than four Boons and more than four Banes are present their effects will begin to cancel each other out.

Example: Added Boons

Suppose Albert, a naval captain, has his ship boarded by pirates. By fortunate circumstance, the fierce rocking of the ship has toppled one of the invaders over on the deck of his ship. Advancing towards the sprawling pirate, Albert draws his blade and slashes down upon the unwelcome guest. Attacking a Prone creature confers 2 boons to Albert's attack roll.

These two boons upgrade the first die in the 3d8 dice pool twice, from a d8 to a d12, resulting in a dice pool of 1d12 + 1d8 + 1d8.

Boons or banes resulting from @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.crucibleConditio]{Conditions} like Prone will be handled automatically by layers of automation in the Crucible software, but additional boons may always be awarded by the Gamemaster prior to any roll as ways to reward players for creative problem solving or inspirational roleplay.

Example: Both Boons and Banes

Dariel is an intrepid outdoorswoman with the Journeyman rank in Survival with a Herbalist specialization. She wishes to identify a herb that may be used to treat poison after an arduous day of traveling. Her specialization as a Herbalist gives her 1 Boon to the roll to identify the correct herb, but her state of exhaustion gives her 2 Banes to her roll. The boon upgrades the first die in the pool to a d10, and the two banes downgrade the third die to a d4, resulting in a dice pool of 1d10 + 1d8 + 1d4.

Mathematically, each Boon increases the expected result of its die by 1 and each Bane decreases the expected result of its die by 1.

Initiative and Turn Order.name: Initiative and Turn Order
Initiative and Turn Order.text:
Initiative reflects your character's swiftness of mind and body - corresponding to how quickly you are able to act in a situation where time is of the essence. Your character's initiative during combat is determined by your Dexterity and Intellect attributes, any passive Initiative Bonus you may have, any situational bonus which allows you to react faster than usual, and an element of random chance.

Rounds and Turns

Each combat encounter is divided into Rounds and Turns. A Round refers to a single set of choices made by the characters in the encounter, where each character gets to act in an order defined by their Initiative. Each round loosely represents 10 seconds of real time, where 6 rounds of combat occur each minute of the encounter's duration. A Turn represents the actions taken by the one character whose turn it is to act in the initiative order.

Initiative Calculation

Your initiative is determined by:

Initiative

=

3d8[Boons,Banes] + ((Dexterity + Intellect) / 4)

A situational bonus to initiative could result from you getting the drop on an enemy, or benefiting from a magical spell which hastens your reactions, alternatively you could face a situational penalty to initiative if your reactions are dulled or slowed by alchemical or magical effects.

Each round of combat you have a pool of Action Points which you may elect to spend in various ways. If you are not immobilized or incapacitated, any unspent Action Points at the end of each round are defined as action reserves which each add a Boon to your Initiative roll for the following round.

Re-rolling initiative every round introduces greater tactical challenge for players who cannot rely completely upon always acting before or after the same foes each round of combat. Being able to convert unspent action points into an initiative bonus in the subsequent round can also promote creative tactical solutions to a variety of combat challenges.

Automatic Initiative

Since Initiative automatically updates every Round of combat, players do not roll for Initiative themselves. Instead this process is automated that every character's initiative roll is automatically performed in order to maintain a satisfying pace to combat encounters.

Incapacitated Combatants

Combatants who are Incapacitated or Dead are automatically placed at Initiative 0 and their turns come last in each Round.

Tiebreaking Procedures

Ties in initiative are resolved by applying the following tiebreaking criteria in order:

  1. Combatants with a higher passive Initiative bonus.

  2. Combatants with more maximum Action.

  3. Adversaries act before Heroes.

  4. Any remaining ties are placed in alphabetical order.

Escalation and Morale

As the tension of combat escalates - so too do the consequences on Morale for combatants. After 6 Rounds of Combat at the start of each subsequent round, the combatant with the highest Initiative result gains additional Morale equal to the numbered Round of combat. The combatant with the lowest Initiative result (excluding Incapacitated and Dead combatants) loses Morale equal to the numbered Round of combat.

Attack Rolls.name: Attack Rolls
Attack Rolls.text:
An Attack Roll is performed by making a Standard Check tested against a certain Defense Score of the target creature. Attack Rolls are made when the effectiveness of an ability is evaluated in opposition to an opponent. Attack Rolls apply to weapon attacks, spell casts, healing abilities, and even some skill checks which are performed in combat.

The player whose character is performing the Attack is always the one to make the roll, while the effectiveness of the defending character or creature is based on their defense scores. The Attack Roll uses the same modified dice pool as a Standard Check, expressed as:

Attack Roll

=

3d8[+Boons, -Banes] + Ability Modifier + Skill Bonus + Enchantment Bonus

The 3d8 dice pool is modified by Boons and Banes. The ability modifier for the attack roll is determined by the scaling formula of the weapon type being used. The Skill Bonus for the attack roll is determined by the character's training in that particular weapon type. The Enchantment Bonus for the roll is determined by the magical properties (if any) of the weapon being used.

Determining Attack Outcomes

The attack is a hit if the result of the Attack Roll exceeds the Defense score of the target. If the result of the attack roll is less than the Defense score, the attack is ineffective. For attacks which target Physical Defense the nature of the miss (Deflected, Blocked, Dodged, or Parried) is further determined by the component Physical Defense scores of the target creature.

Overflow and Damage

The amount by which the Attack Roll exceeded the Defense score is called Overflow. This Overflow amount is multiplied by a Damage Multiplier which is usually 1, but occasionally higher or lower. Then any additive Damage Bonus is applied, and lastly any Resistance possessed by the target creature is subtracted from the result.

Overflow

=

Attack Roll - Defense Score

Damage

=

(Overflow × Damage Multiplier) + Damage Bonus - Target Resistance

While Damage Resistance is a powerful way for creatures to reduce incoming damage, such damage cannot be mitigated entirely. Abilities which deal direct (immediate) damage that surpass the target's Defense Score always deal at least 1 point of damage to their target Resource.

Abilities which deal indirect damage-over-time, however, can have the effects of that indirect damage reduced to zero by Resistance.

Critical Hits and Misses

If the Attack Roll exceeds the Defense Score by an amount greater than the attacker's Critical Hit Threshold (6 in most cases) it becomes a Critical Hit. Similarly if the Attack Roll is lower than the Defense Score by an amount greater than the attacker's Critical Miss Threshold (6 in most cases) it becomes a Critical Miss.

A Critical Hit does not directly increase the damage of an attack - although because of the way that Overflow contributes to total damage, Critical Hits always deal more damage than normal hits.

Critical Hits and Critical Misses present opportunities for other things to occur. Many talents allow your character to cause special effects when achieving a Critical Hit, or to react to an enemy if an incoming attack is a Critical Miss.

Critical Hit Effects

Zenith the Monk has both the Concussive Blows and Battle Focus talents. Zenith rolls a 29 on a Strike attack against a terrible Swamp Troll with a 19 Physical Defense. This attack results in a Critical Hit and as a result the Swamp Troll is Staggered because of the Concussive Blows talent and Zenith recovers +1 Focus because of the Battle Focus talent.

Movement.name: Movement
Movement.text:
Movement is one of the most important actions that characters in Crucible will perform in combat.

Movement and positioning in Crucible uses a fine-grained 1 foot grid which provides excellent features like tactically significant movement and positioning, meaningful differences in creature sizes and weapon ranges, and intuitive areas of effect.

Distances in the Crucible system are defined in feet. The grid size of Scenes in Foundry Virtual Tabletop will be automatically adjusted to have a subgrid with distance units of 1 foot.

Measurement distance is computed using the Exact √2 diagonal measurement mode.

Many combat actions a character can perform involve the Movement tag. Such actions allow you to move a certain number of feet up to our equal to your character's Stride attribute. The distance allowed by a Movement action cannot be broken up or interrupted. There is no leftover movement saved across actions if you move less than your Stride.

There are no facing mechanics in Crucible, meaning that it does not matter which direction your Token is facing on the map, your character is able to perceive and act in a full 360 degree radius unless otherwise limited by some special effect or condition.

Movement Cost Calculation

The Action cost of a given Movement is computed as follows:

  1. Distance is computed center-point to center-point, where the distance of diagonal movement is computed using the Exact √2 diagonal measurement mode.

  2. Effective Distance is compted by applying the following modifiers in order:

    1. Status Conditions are applied first, as described below.

    2. The effects of Terrain are applied second.

    3. Modifiers resulting from the Movement Type are applied.

  3. The Action cost of the movement is computed as:

Action Cost

=

ceil(Effective Distance / Stride)

  1. If a Free Move is available, the final Action Cost of the movement is reduced by 1.

Movement Conditions

The following Status Conditions affect the measurement and cost of movement.

Slowed

The Effective Distance traveled by any movement is doubled.

Hastened

The Effective Distance traveled by any movement is halved.

Restrained

Movement is impossible.

Movement Types

The following Movement Types are supported:

Walk

No change to Effective Distance.

Step

You move carefully and do not provoke Disengagement, but your Effective Distance traveled is doubled.

Crawl

You move while Prone and your Effective Distance traveled is doubled.

Jump

Equivalent to Walk, but required by certain actions or to surmount certain obstacles.

Swim

Used while moving in waist-deep or deeper water, your Effective Distance traveled is doubled.

Fly

Equivalent to Walk, but used by creatures which can fly or hover.

Free Movement

Each creature has the opportunity to perform one free Movement action per round of Combat. This means that the first Action performed each round which involves the Movement tag is discounted at -1 Action cost. This will typically make the action free to perform, but in some cases may simply reduce its overall cost.

Free Movement is not available to creatures wearing Heavy armor or those who are Prone. Additionally, the Slowed condition increases the cost of Movement actions, however the first such movement per round is still discounted.

Terrain

Crucible will eventually support declaring certain grid spaces as difficult terrain which slow movement while traversing them. Movement costs are doubled within difficult terrain. Until automation for this feature is added, difficult terrain can be applied manually to movement costs however the current Alpha Playtest ignores the presence of difficult terrain.

Cover

Certain terrain or obstacles can be counted as Cover - providing additional protection from incoming Spell or Weapon attacks. When a direct single-target attack passes through such an obstacle, the target of the attack is in Cover. Cover is classified according to the following types:

Cover Type

Banes to Attacks

Complete Cover

Direct attacks not possible

Hard Cover

+4 Banes

Partial Hard Cover

+2 Banes

Soft Cover

+1 Banes

Area of effect attacks from abilities with target types like Cone, Blast, or Pulse ignore the effects of Cover.

In the future, definition of cover and automation of banes occurring from cover may be automated in the Crucible system. For the time being, Banes added due to Cover should be added manually when attack rolls are made.

Skill Attacks.name: Skill Attacks
Skill Attacks.text:
Skill Attacks are Actions which involve use of one of Crucible's 12 @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.skills0000000000]{Skills} in a tactical way during combat. Actions which use a Skill in this way perform the Skill Attack by rolling a Skill Test opposed by the target's passive score in the same Skill.

Krag wants to use his intimidating demeanor to break the Morale of some attacking Goblins. Krag, an Adept in the Intimidation skill, uses the Intimidate Action targeting a nearby Goblin and rolls the Skill Attack, producing a total result of 27 compared to the Goblin's passive Intimidation score of 14. This success results in 17 Void Damage dealt to the Goblin's Morale, causing it to become Broken and attempt to flee.

Reactions.name: Reactions
Reactions.text:
Reactions are a special type of Action which can only be taken on some other creature's turn in combat. Reactions have specific triggering conditions like you dodge an melee Strike attack or an ally you can see achieves a critical hit. Reactions require spending Action or Focus points, and therefore cannot be performed if you do not have the required resources - even if the condition for the reaction is otherwise met.

A creature is unable to perform Reactions if they are Unaware or Incapacitated.

Actions.name: Actions
Actions.text:
Actions encompass the activities, techniques, spellcraft, and attacks which are performed during a combat encounter. Actions modify, either positively or negatively, the resource pools of combatants until the encounter is resolved.

Action Attributes

Actions have the following properties which explain how they are used.

Action Cost

Most actions incur a cost in Action Points. Action Points signify and represent the time and physical exertion required in order to perform an action in the midst of combat.

Focus Cost

Some actions may incur a cost in Focus Points. Focus Points signify and represent the mental energy and concentration needed to perform exceptional feats of heroism, spellcraft, or martial prowess.

Action Tags

The functionality of Actions relies on a large set of tags which describe how that action behaves. Each tag can change certain aspects of the Action like it's prerequisites, it's target, the type of damage it deals, what type of dice roll is applied, whether Boons or Banes are added to the roll, and more. A table of Action Tags is listed at the bottom of this page.

Target Type

Each action defines a specific target type which describes the affected creatures or area-of-effect of the action. A list of possible target types is provided in the following section.

Target Scope

In addition to the range and area of effect of the Action described by the target type, each Action defines a target scope which defines which creature dispositions it can affect. Action scopes include "all creatures", "allies only", "enemies only", "self only".

Activation Condition

Certain actions may require a specific triggering condition to be met in order for the action to be eligible for use. If present, this prerequisite condition will be listed on the action, for example, the Defensive Roll action has an activation condition You Dodge an incoming melee Strike.

Applied Effects

Certain Actions may apply Active Effects to creatures they affect. Any effects applied by the Action will be listed on its card with a stated duration in combat Turns or Rounds. Some effects last until otherwise removed, having unlimited duration.

Target Types

Blast

This action affects creatures within a circular area of effect centered on a grid space chosen by the character performing the action. The Blast action also specifies a Size which describes the radius of effect and a Distance which describes the maximum range between the originating character and the chosen center-point of the blast.

Cone

This action affects creatures within a narrow cone of effect. The Cone originates at the center of the grid space of the character performing the action. The Cone has an angle of 60 degrees and a specified Distance which describes the range of the ability in grid spaces. Cone templates may be placed at 45 degree increments only.

Fan

This action affects creatures with a broad cone of effect. The Fan originates at the center of the grid space of the character performing the action. The Fan has an angle of 120 degrees and a specified Distance which describes the range of the ability in grid spaces. Fan templates may be placed at 45 degree increments only.

None

This action has no specific target. It may cause certain effects to occur but those effects are not specific to any particular creature. This target type is not typically used.

Pulse

This action affects creatures in a circular area of effect centered on the character performing the action. The Pulse has a specified Distance which describes the radius of the ability in grid spaces.

Ray

This action affects creatures in a straight line originating from the character performing the action. The Ray has a specified Distance which describes the length of its effect in grid spaces.

Self

This action only involves or affects the character or creature which performs it. Self-target abilities affect no other creatures and have no range requirement.

Single

This action targets some number of individual creatures other than the creature which performs it. Single target actions also specify a Number which describes the number of creatures targeted and a Distance which describes the range of the ability in grid spaces.

Wall

This action targets creatures in a straight line perpendicular to the character performing the action. Actions of the Wall type also specify a Size which describes the breadth of the wall and a Distance which describes the maximum range at which the center of the wall may be placed.

Engagement and Flanking.name: Engagement and Flanking
Engagement and Flanking.text:
Engagement describes the total number of opposing Combatants that you can simultaneously battle against without becoming more vulnerable. The base Engagement for Protagonist characters is 1, while the base Engagement for Adversary characters is equal to their Size - 2 with a minimum of 1.

When a character is adjacent to multiple enemies where the number of engaged enemies equals or exceeds their Engagement score, that character is said to be Fully Engaged. Some conditions or action prerequisites may only occur when a creature is Fully Engaged.

To help visualize how Engagement and Flanking mechanics works, there is a special toggle that can be used in the Tokens Layer of the Scene Controls UI on the left side of the screen. While enabled, the Engagement rectangles and flanked status of a creature will be visualized to help understand its current status.

Flanking

Flanking occurs when you and your allies team up to combat an opponent. When a creature is Engaged with a number of creatures greater than its Engagement score it has the Flanked condition. The Flanked condition has multiple stages, and each stage of Flanked contributes +1 Boon to attack rolls made against that creature.

Flanked Stage

=

Number of Engaged Enemies
- Engagement Score
- Engagement Bonus from Adjacent Allies

Krag, a heavily armored fighter, has an Engagement score of 3, with bonuses from his True Grit talent and from his Heater Shield with the Engaging property. Krag can engage with three opposing combatants simultaneously without them acquiring any Flanking bonus against him. However if Krag is surrounded by five Goblins, he would have the Flanked 2 condition and each Goblin's attacks would benefit from +2 Boons (5 engaged enemies - 3 Engagement).

While having more Engaged enemies increases your Flanked condition, having adjacent allies who are supporting you can nullify flanking. Allies contribute their own Engagement as a bonus to yours if you share enemies in common that you are both Engaged with.

Krag, from our previous example, is still surrounded by 5 Goblins and is Flanked 2. His ally Jinora comes to join the fray. Jinora has an Engagement score of 2. When Jinora moves next to Krag, and into a position where Jinora can engage at least 2 of the Goblins, Krag's Flanked condition is removed because Jinora's 2 Engagement adds to Krag's own Engagement score, allowing Krag to engage up to 5 enemies.

A status effect condition when a creature is Flanked is automatically computed and added whenever a character moves into or out of Engagement with other adversaries. The Flanked effect automatically applies the correct number of boons to attack rolls against the Flanked creature.

Disengagement

When an opponent attempts to disengage from you in melee combat it becomes temporarily vulnerable, allowing you to perform a Disengagement Strike, an attack with your mainhand weapon which costs 1 Focus point to perform. You may not make a Disengagement Attack if you are Unaware of the enemy moving away or if you are Flanked by other remaining opponents.

The Goblins in our previous example have decided that Krag is too tough and it is advisable to disengage in search of more vulnerable prey. Two of the four goblins may move away from Krag without reciprocity, because Krag is otherwise Fully Engaged and therefore cannot retaliate. When the third goblin moves away, however, Krag spends 1 Focus point to perform a Disengagement Strike, burying his battle axe in the back of the retreating evildoer!

There is a safe means of retreating from melee combat, which is to Move Cautiously. This mode of movement only permits you to move a single space, but it denies enemies with whom you were previously engaged the opportunity to perform a Disengagement Attack.

Concealment and Surprise.name: Concealment and Surprise
Concealment and Surprise.text:
The @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.skills0000000000#exploration-skills]{Stealth} skill, paired with concealment from terrain are mechanics which allow creatures to be undetected by their enemies. Identification of hidden enemies is generally performed using an opposed @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.skills0000000000#exploration-skills]{Awareness} test or a passive Awareness check.

A character or adversary may be Unaware, a status condition which render them more vulnerable to attacks. Creatures that are Unaware act at Initiative 1 in Combat, last aside for Incapacitated creatures. Once a creature is no longer Unaware, they roll Initiative and act as normal for subsequent rounds of combat.

Complete mechanics, status conditions, and automation for stealth, concealment, unaware opponents, and surprise will be developed and added in future phases of development.

Heroism.name: Heroism
Heroism.text:
Actions taken during Combat generate Heroism which accumulates until it reaches a threshold at which point every Hero in the Combat encounter gains a Heroism Point. Heroism is a resource that allows protagonists to perform legendary or iconic feats of power or resilience.

Heroism is accumulated by any Action which applies healing, damage, or effects to some other character. Actions which only target yourself, like Move or Defend do not contribute towards Heroism. The actions of both allies and adversaries count towards Heroism accumulation. The amount of Heroism accumulated by each Action is equal to its Action cost.

The progress of Heroism accumulation is visualized at the top of the Combat Tracker. A customizable game setting exists to configure whether this progress bar is visible to all players or only to Gamemasters. If you are new to the Crucible system, we encourage you to allow this progress bar to be visible to everyone, but once you are used to the rules of the system concealing it from players can help reduce metagaming that may occur from players trying to precisely anticipate the award of their next Heroism point.

The number of Action Points that need to be spent in order to yield a Heroism Point depends on the number of Hero characters in the Combat encounter:

Action per Heroism

=

Number of Heroes × 12

Example: Ray of Life

Suppose Kagura, a powerful Healer, casts a spell Composed Ray of Life which heals two of her allies and costs 5 Action to cast. Since this spell heals other characters, this action contributes 5 Action towards Heroism accumulation. If this accumulation were enough to fill the Heroism meter, then Kagura and each of her allies would immediately gain +1 Heroism.

With her remaining Action for the turn, Kagura uses Defend which costs 1 Action. Since this Action only affects herself, it does not contribute towards Heroism accumulation.

Balance and Difficulty.name: Balance and Difficulty
Balance and Difficulty.text:
Crucible is designed to be a challenging combat experience which will require players to think tactically, work together, and effectively develop their characters' powers. Encounter balance in Crucible is managed using several fundamental levers.

  1. Convenient scaling of Adversary Level and Threat rating which makes adjusting difficulty for differing party levels or sizes relatively easy to do.

  2. The secondary Wounds and Morale pools that hero characters uniquely have which accumulate and absorb variance due to bad luck.

  3. The Gamemaster, who plays a pivotal role in interpreting the storytelling needs for each combat moment.

Balancing Encounters

Encounters in Crucible are typically balanced such that the cumulative Threat of all enemies is equal to the cumulative Threat of hero characters plus any allied non-player characters. The ease of adjusting the Level or Threat of an @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.v1dqTT3NI35lFNxM.JournalEntryPage.WH0YSVcYo09aHNZ2]{adversary } makes it easy to adjust an encounter to this point of balance ahead of time.

Encounters balanced in this way have an approximately 50% chance of going in the party's favor and a 50% chance of going in the enemies' favor. This does not mean that the party "loses" or "dies" half the time, but rather in 50% of balanced encounters the party will suffer some number of Wounds.

Wounds Regulate Luck 

The accumulation of these Wounds is something that the heroes must manage over the course of multiple encounters or days. Since adversaries do not have Wounds, only Health this is an intentional advantage in favor of Hero characters.

In any single balanced encounter if the heroes get lucky or play well, they will win without suffering any Wounds. If the heroes play poorly or experience bad luck, they will probably still win but suffer Wounds in the process. Wounds are a mechanism to regulate swings in luck while also requiring the party to be effective combatants most of the time.

The Role of the Gamemaster

Lastly, the Gamemaster plays a pivotal role in ensuring the fun and balance of combat. Enemies in Crucible are generally optimized such that they can be very effective at their main combat style. This is done because we assume that player characters are also designed and progressed with — to at least some extent — combat effectiveness in mind.

It is not a goal of Crucible to require that every player character be maximally optimized or that every decision in combat be one that optimizes for victory rather than advancing the story being told. It is therefore important that the Gamemaster to calibrate the optimization of their own play to match the party and the needs of the storytelling moment.

Adversaries in Crucible can and should be fallible in the decisions that they make. Enemies can, and often should, spend their Action and Focus in combat on actions that maintain tension and stakes while prioritizing the needs of the story rather than actions that specifically optimize to defeat the heroes.

Rest and Recovery.name: Rest and Recovery
Rest and Recovery.text:
After expending resources in combat or via other types of challenges, characters will need to replenish their reserves. There are two special Actions that are used for this purpose:

Recover

A short rest that requires 10 minutes during which time resources of Health, Morale, Action, and Focus are fully replenished. Any existing Heroism is removed. Certain special Actions can be performed during a Recovery. Unless otherwise stated, only one such Action may be performed per character.

Rest

A long rest that requires 10 hours during which the characters have time to eat, sleep, recover, and perform other downtime actions. Rest delivers all the benefits of Recover, but also any accumulated Wounds or Madness are reduced by an amount equal to the character's level. Certain special Actions can be performed during a Rest. Unless otherwise stated, only one such Action may be performed per character.

Defenses.name: Defenses
Defenses.text:
Defenses are a set of attributes for each character which define how difficult certain actions are to take against that character. The higher a defense value, the harder it is to perform an action which targets that defense. Success on a test against a defense target requires the roll to exceed the defense value, the defender is successful on a tie.

The defense types in the Crucible system are:

Physical Defense

Physical Defense describes how difficult the creature is to hit with physical attacks, typically melee or ranged weapon strikes. Physical Defense is composed of four components. Total Physical Defense is equal to:

Physical Defense

=

Armor + Dodge + Parry + Block

When an attack misses because it is less than or equal to the Physical Defense total, it is assigned a type of miss based on the proportional mixture of Physical Defense components.

Armor

Protection offered by worn equipment or organic attributes like scales or chitin. Strikes which fail to hit and are defended by Armor assume the Deflected outcome. Unlike other physical defense outcomes, Deflection still results in some damage as long as the attack roll was not a Critical Failure; more than 6 less than the Physical Defense target. The residual damage dealt from a Deflection is also called a Glancing Blow.

Dodge

Protection offered by physical quickness and agility. Strikes which fail to hit and are defended by the Dodge defense assume the Dodged outcome. Dodged attacks deal no damage and provide opportunity for dodge-based reactions.

Parry

Protection offered by guarding against an attack using an equipped weapon. Strikes which fail to hit and are defended by the Parry defense assume the Parried outcome. Parried attacks deal no damage and provide opportunity for parry-based reactions.

Block

Protection offered by guarding against an attack using an equipped shield or blocking weapon. Strikes which fail to hit and are defended by the Block defense assume the Blocked outcome. Blocked attacks deal no damage and provide opportunity for block-based reactions.

Non-Physical Defenses

The three non-physical defenses are used to protect against spells or other abilities which are non-corporeal or intangible in nature.

Fortitude

Fortitude Defense describes a character's ability to withstand bodily harm. Fortitude is modified by Strength and Wisdom which represent physical resistance and mental resilience respectively. Fortitude defense is calculated as:

Fortitude Defense

=

12 + ((Strength + Wisdom) / 2) + Fortitude Bonus

Willpower

Willpower Defense describes a character's ability to withstand mental or emotional attacks. Willpower is modified by Toughness and Presence which represent physical grit and mental determination respectively. Willpower defense is calculated as:

Willpower Defense

=

12 + ((Toughness + Presence) / 2) + Willpower Bonus

Reflex

Reflex Defense describes a character's ability to avoid harm that would otherwise occur in a specific area. Reflex is modified by Dexterity and Intellect which represent quickness of body and rapidity of thought respectively. Reflex defense is calculated as:

Reflex Defense

=

12 + ((Dexterity + Intellect) / 2) + Reflex Bonus

Note that Reflex is typically used as the defense type for intangible - but otherwise physical - sources of harm, while Physical Defense is used to defend against tangible attacks.

Defense Bonuses

Bonuses to these non-physical defenses may be obtained through Talents or magical Equipment.

Restoration Thresholds

Restoration Thresholds describe a pair of defenses which dictate how challenging it is to restore a creature's resources through healing or rallying actions.

Healing Threshold

Healing Threshold describes how difficult it is to restore the Health of a creature. As creatures become more severely wounded, they grow more difficult to heal. This provides a measure of attrition which requires adventures to carefully manage their accumulation of Wounds over time. Healing threshold is calculated as:

Healing Threshold

=

12 + (Wounds / 10) - Bonus

Rallying Threshold

Rallying Threshold describes how difficult it is to restore the Morale of a creature. As creatures become more psychologically damaged they become more difficult to rally. This provides a measure of attrition which requires adventurers to carefully manage their accumulation of Madness over time. Rallying threshold is calculated as:

Rallying Threshold

=

12 + (Madness / 10) - Bonus

Threshold Bonuses

Bonuses to these Restoration Threshold defenses may be obtained through Talents or magical Equipment. Since higher thresholds make a character more difficult to heal, bonuses to these defenses lower the threshold instead of increasing it.

Resources.name: Resources
Resources.text:
Resources refers to the family of attributes which represent a character's wellbeing and ability to act. Each resource is a "pool", featuring a current and maximum value. The minimum value for all resources is zero.

Physical and Mental Health

Maintaining the physical and mental health of your character is an ever-present challenge. Crucible uses two separate pools to represent the hero's state of wellbeing.

Health and Wounds

The physical health of a character is modeled using two resource pools. Health is a temporary resource which begins full and is decreased when a character sustains damage in combat. Wounds are a permanent resource which increase when a character suffers grievous injury.

If the Health pool is reduced to zero, the character becomes Incapacitated and begins to suffer Wounds. If the Wounds meter reaches its maximum, the character becomes Dead.

Morale and Madness

The mental health of a character is similarly modeled using two resource pools. Morale is a temporary resource which begins full and is decreased as the character suffers stress or trauma. Madness is a permanent resource which increases when a character suffers grievous mental strain.

If the Morale pool is reduced to zero, the character becomes Broken and begins to suffer Madness. If the Madness meter reaches its maximum, the character becomes Insane.

Capacity for Action

Two resource pools define a character's ability to take action during game situations.

Action

Action describes a character's capacity for rapid action during each round of a combat encounter. Characters typically have a pool of 6 Action, all six of which replenish at the start of their turn in combat.

Focus

Focus describes a character's capacity for extraordinary feats of heroism or magic. A character's Focus is replenished when they successfully rest, but during the midst of combat Focus must be used thoughtfully as it will not naturally replenish.

Heroism

Heroism is a special generated resource that allows you to perform spectacular feats of magic or heroic prowess. Heroism is earned over the course of — typically longer — combat encounters allowing you to narratively unleash your most powerful abilities once the tension of battle has peaked!

Recovering Resources

During Combat, Health and Morale may only be recovered by Actions or Talents which provide Restoration. Outside of Combat, it is possible to use the Recover action which consumes 10 minutes of time and fully replenishes your Health, Morale, Action, and Focus pools.

In order to reduce the accumulation of Wounds or Madness, long-term Rest is required. Rest mechanics are not implemented in Playtest One. The means and rate at which Wounds and Madness are reduced will be more fully articulated in a later phase of development.

Resistances and Vulnerability.name: Resistances and Vulnerability
Resistances and Vulnerability.text:
Damage Resistance allows a character in Crucible to shrug off or succumb to more damage than normal. Specific creature types may be vulnerable to certain types of damage, conversely some of the most terrifying adversaries are ones that can ignore significant portions of damage that they take.

Most creatures which are resistant to a certain damage type are vulnerable to some other damage type - if you encounter a creature which is overly effective at withstanding your blows - switch tactics!

Damage Types

The Crucible system uses the following 12 Damage Types, each of which has a corresponding Resistance or Vulnerability. Additionally, each damage type has an associated @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.crucibleConditio.JournalEntryPage.conditionsOvervi]{Condition} which can be caused as a consequence of that damage type, usually as a result of a Critical Hit.

Physical Damage Types

Damage Resistance

When an Action deals damage, that damage may be reduced by an amount of Resistance that the target creature has. This amount of resistance may even reduce the damage caused by the Action to be zero!

Example: Damage Resistance

Suppose a mechanical automaton, a Brass Sentinel, has resistance of +5 to Slashing damage. If the Brass Sentinel receives an attack that deals 13 Slashing damage, the effective damage dealt is reduced to 8 Slashing Damage.

Damage Vulnerability

When a creature is vulnerable to a type of damage dealt, the amount of damage dealt is increased by the amount of the vulnerability. This increase in damage is limited by the base amount of damage dealt; maximum damage against a vulnerable target is two times the amount of damage dealt.

Example: Damage Vulnerability

Suppose a volatile Fire Elemental has vulnerability of -20 to Cold damage. If the elemental is dealt 7 Cold damage before vulnerability is applied, the total result will be 14 Cold damage.

Damage Immunity

In exceptional cases, a creature may be entirely Immune to a certain damage type. In this case, the creature never takes damage of that type no matter its magnitude.

Ability Scores.name: Ability Scores
Ability Scores.text:
Ability Scores approximate facets of a character's physical and mental capability. All dice checks in the Crucible system are modified by at least one ability score of the character performing the test. Ability Scores are also used to calculate a number of secondary attributes for your character, such as @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Defenses00000000]{Defenses} and @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Resources0000000]{Resource} pools.

A score of 1 typically indicates an area of weakness compared to peers while an ability score of 12 is reserved for supernatural entities, great beasts, or heroes who are unparalleled in their power. Some adversaries may have a score of 0 in a particular ability score. This convention is used when a particular ability is not applicable for that particular creature.

The ability scores used in the Crucible system are:

Strength

Strength is a hero's physical potency, brawn and might. Strength affects Health, use of melee weaponry, Fortitude defense, and carrying capacity.

Dexterity

Dexterity refers to both agility and precision. Dexterity affects the use of precision weapons, Initiative in taking action, as well as the Dodge and Reflex @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Defenses00000000]{Defenses}.

Toughness

Toughness defines physical hardiness and resilience. Toughness affects Health and contributes to the Fortitude @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Defenses00000000]{Defense}.

Wisdom

Wisdom is a hero's mental potency, depth and breadth of knowledge. Wisdom influences Morale, maximum Focus Points, and the Willpower @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Defenses00000000]{Defense}.

Intellect

Intellect refers to mental flexibility, swiftness, and precision of thought. Intellect influences Initiative in taking action and the Reflex @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Defenses00000000]{Defense}.

Presence

Presence is a hero's mental and emotional hardiness, charm, and personality. Presence influences Morale, Focus Points, and the Willpower @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Defenses00000000]{Defense}.

Talents.name: Talents
Talents.text:
Talents represent unique combinations of abilities a particular character may have, and provide a level of customization and progression beyond skill advancement. Talents allow characters to define their role more clearly as they advance, growing steadily in power. Newly created characters begin with a small number of Talent Points, gaining more points at each level.

Outside of the @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6]{Character Creation} process, you can access the Talent Tree for a character at any time by opening the Talents tab and clicking the "Open Talent Tree" button.

Interaction with the talent tree is similar to interaction with Scenes in ordinary Foundry VTT usage. Pan the tree using right-click and drag, and use mouse-wheel to zoom in and out. Left clicking any Node will expand it to reveal the Talents it may contain.

Left-clicking a Talent purchases that talent if you have points available, while right-clicking it will remove that talent from your character.

You may reset your purchases on the Talent Tree at any time by clicking the Reset button at the bottom.

Tree Layout

Crucible's Talent Tree is divided into six sections, with each section representing a different @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.abilityScores000]{Ability} which affects scaling and other aspects of those talents.

The Talent Tree is composed of several subcomponents which help you plot growth and progression for your character.

Nodes

Each sextant of the Talent tree is composed of a number of Nodes which can contain one or more Talents. A Node which lie closer to the border between two sextants will often feature abilities which relate to the themes of both ability scores.

Starting Nodes occur at the inner-most ring, and contain talents that are often prerequisites for later talents in the tree. These starter talents are best thought of as the first steps in defining what makes your character different from another in terms of their specific set of special abilities.

Talents

Talents are the smallest unit of the talent tree. Each talent grants your character-specific abilities or bonuses. Many Talents have requirements which must be met before they can be purchased, such as attaining a certain level of Ability bonus or degree of training in a Skill.

Training Talents

Training talents are specific types of talent nodes that grant advancements to Skills, or progress Weapon or Tradecraft training. Weapon or Tradecraft Training Talents authorize your character to use particular weapons or to craft particular types of schematics, Skill Training Talents award the following benefits:

Bonus

Rank

Scale

-2

Untrained

You are decidedly as good at this skill as the average person who has absolutely no education or professional training related to it.

2

Novice

You have received training in the basic practices common across all parts of that skill.

3

Journeyman

You've reached some degree of advanced training and know some of the less common principles of that particular skill.

4

Adept

You have exceeded all the bounds of professional training. There is nothing more about your skills that you can learn from others. All that is left is to perfect your understanding.

5

Master

You have mastered this skill. There is nothing more to learn about it.

Signature Talents

Talent nodes at the outer edges of the Talent Tree contain Signature Talents, powerful bonuses that "Spellblade" or "Dread Lord" which offer iconic abilities. Signature Talents represent the culmination of the abilities required to select them, and are mirrored across two ability scores. Taking a Signature Talent forms a bridge to its paired ability score, allowing you to continue your path of progression into that sextant regardless of whether you have already purchased lower-tier Talents.

Ancestry.name: Ancestry
Ancestry.text:
Ancestry classifies the biology and physiology of a character in Crucible. Fantasy settings may feature a spectrum of species which are playable as characters. Crucible supports defining Ancestries for each of these options which are narratively and mechanically appropriate for your own game.

Creating Ancestries

Crucible is not designed for a specific game setting. Gamemasters are encouraged to create or modify Ancestries to fit the lore of their own worlds. To configure an Ancestry in Crucible, create a new Item with the Ancestry type. Fill out the Ancestry configuration sheet to select a primary Ability score, a secondary Ability score, and optionally Resistance and Vulnerability to two different damage types. Every Ancestry may either have both a Resistance and a Vulnerability, or neither.

Each Ancestry includes:

  • A Primary Ability Score (which begins at 3)

  • A Secondary Ability Score (which begins at 2)

  • A Size value in grid spaces (typically 4)

  • A Stride value in grid spaces that determines the starting movement speed (typically 10)

  • Optional: A Damage Resistance to a certain type of damage (+3 resistance) — If a Damage Resistance is selected, a Damage Vulnerability MUST be selected.

  • Optional: A Damage Vulnerability to a certain type of damage (-3 vulnerability) — If a Damage Vulnerability is selected, a Damage Resistance MUST be selected.

  • An Ancestral Talent which grants a specific special ability or knowledge to a character of that ancestry.

Included Ancestries

Flexible Ancestry

Crucible allows use of custom ancestries by providing a way for GMs to configure their own compendium packs to use as a source during character creation. To add your compendium as a source, go to Configure Settings ➤ Crucible ➤ Configure Compendium Sources.

Role-playing games inspire and thrill us with tales of heroes who are exceptional and unique. Biological traits do not guarantee physical attributes, nor are species meant to be homogenous or monolithic (unless narratively intended). Gamemasters are empowered and encouraged to modify or customize Ancestries to suit the stories they and their players wish to tell. Consider Ancestral traits as suggestions rather than requirements.

Alex (a player) intends to roleplay as an Orc who, at the beginning of their journey, is not particularly tough but instead unusually wise. In such cases the initial Ability Scores of 3 Strength and 2 Toughness that the example Orcish Ancestry provides are at odds with the character development Alex desires. The Gamemaster can work with Alex to create a variation of the Orcish ancestry which offers different starting Ability Scores, for example by swapping the Primary Ability from Strength to Wisdom.

Background.name: Background
Background.text:
Background defines the cultural upbringing, professional training, career to date, and other aspects of a hero's past before the events of the game's story. These are intended to give depth to a character and some measure of explanation to the origins of their particular skillset and capabilities.

Creating a Background

Crucible is not designed for a specific game setting. Gamemasters are encouraged to create or modify Backgrounds to fit the lore of their own worlds. To configure a Background in Crucible, create a new Item with the Background type. Fill out the Background configuration sheet to select four acquired Skills which begin at Novice tier and one acquired Talent.

Each Background includes:

  • Novice Skills (typically 2)

  • Knowledge Areas (typically 2)

  • Known Languages

  • Talents (typically at least one weapon training talent and one additional talent)

Knowledge Areas.name: Knowledge Areas
Knowledge Areas.text:
Knowledge Areas (or sometimes just called "Knowledges") are specific enhancements that reflect notable areas of a hero's understanding of some specialized training. While most knowledge areas come as a result of a @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.backgrounds00000]{Background} selected during @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6]{Character Creation}, it is possible to attain knowledge areas in other ways during character progression.

Knowledge areas are still being implemented and developed as a mechanical aspect of Crucible and may change over the course of the next several iterations.

While knowledge areas do not grant a specific mechanical bonus, they are often used in combination with skill checks:

  • Sometimes, a Knowledge will substitute for a Skill Check that would otherwise be required.

  • Sometimes, a Knowledge will provide certain Boons towards the attempted Skill Check.

  • Sometimes, a Knowledge may be a prerequisite condition for even attempting a Skill Check.

Skills.name: Skills
Skills.text:
Skills represent the education or degree of professional training your character has received. These Skills might have been learned as part of their @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6.JournalEntryPage.uCwStnXHoUCV2TrK]{Background} or some other aspect of their life experience. Skills progress when a character selects a Training Talent. During @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6]{Character Creation}, some Training Talents are awarded during the selection of a Background.

More information on Training Talents can be found in @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.talents000000000]{Talents}.

Exploration Skills

Athletics

The Athletics skill represents the ability to undertake and surmount physical challenges. These could involve traversal of difficult terrain like climbing, running, or swimming, or could involve feats of strength, endurance, or flexibility.

Awareness

Awareness is a measure of your skill in translating sensory input into useful information. A character with high Awareness is able to notice and interpret details that others might miss, and is able to quickly identify and react to threats.

Stealth

Stealth covers the ability to hide effectively, to move without making a sound, to disguise oneself, and to otherwise use your environment to hide your presence. Those trained in Stealth focus on finding ways to remain unnoticed, whether sneaking in solitude through a dark alley at night, or blending in at a celebration at a crowded ballroom.

Wilderness

Those skilled in Wilderness learn to create shelter where there is none, identify which water is safe to drink and which is not, and locate sources of food in even the most inhospitable places, and to otherwise survive in harsh environments.

Knowledge Skills

Arcana

Whether the focus of the education is magical or religious in nature, Arcana encompasses the study of esoteric knowledge. Students of Arcana learn fundamental principles of metaphysics, study spiritual beings and deities, runic theory and ritual, the nature of chaos and order, and the history of how magical and spiritual forces impact societies and cultures.

Medicine

The study of Medicine is a practical one, with a focus on studying the mechanical, biological components that make up living creatures, the ailments that can afflict them, and the ways to best treat injury and illness alike.

Science

Science is concerned with physical phenomena and examining the world through the lens of logic, reason, mathematics, and the use of structured observation. A student of science learns to posit and confirm theories, analyze the construction of physical objects and machines, and apply mathematical thinking.

Society

The Society skill is most often used for the purposes of research or understanding into the nuanced aspects of a social situation. Those educated in the workings of Society study the factors which contribute to social structures. Knowledge of Society is used to establish historical or socio-political context, to identify the social rank of particular individuals, or to otherwise draw connections between a person or place and its most likely contributors.

Social Skills

Deception

Deception most commonly comes into play when a character is attempting to lie or mislead others, forge documents, or pierce the veil of lies others construct. Those who pursue an education in Deception are often politicians, diplomats, spies, thieves, or other professions for whom flexibility in the truth is a necessity.

Diplomacy

Diplomacy is rolled most often to persuade others to see things your way. A skill most commonly found in the politically savvy or influential orators, Diplomacy allows for the use of rhetoric and emotional appeals to inspire and convince others. Diplomats focus their efforts on the use of words, rather than deeds, to change opinions and inspire emotional reactions.

Intimidation

Intimidation is used to force others to do your bidding, whether through displays of aggression or threats of violence. Those trained in the art of intimidation are capable of using their words and actions to inspire fear in others, to demonstrate dominance or press others into subservience. Those who train their skill in intimidation need not necessarily be physically imposing in terms of stature, for words and deeds can be equally capable of inspiring fear.

Performance

Those who study Performance learn, above all else, how to use their talents to inspire and entertain others whether through music, dance, storytelling, or other forms of artistic expression.. Performers learn verse and music, use of pigment and light, poetry and story, dance and even physical feats to evoke emotional reactions in others.

Skill Checks

There are often situations that require a character to confirm their capabilities. At any time GM may call for a Skill Check— a simple roll to test whether you have sufficient skill to perform an action or recall some piece of information. Each skill is associated with two @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.abilityScores000]{Abilities}.

You can roll a skill check at any time from the skill tab of your character sheet, simply by clicking on the skill name.

Skill checks use the same equation for calculation that a @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.KBDiQbnSfnRYG7mi.JournalEntryPage.WpBewuNfFJp1ZJRt#standard-check]{Standard Check} does.

A character's skill rank is determined by their degree of training, adding a bonus to checks made for that skill. Each skill has 4 ranks as well as an 'untrained' rank.

Bonus

Rank

Scale

-2

Untrained

You are decidedly as good at this skill as the average person who has absolutely no education or professional training related to it.

2

Novice

You have received training in the basic practices common across all parts of that skill.

3

Journeyman

You've reached some degree of advanced training and know some of the less common principles of that particular skill.

4

Adept

You have exceeded all the bounds of professional training. There is nothing more about your skills that you can learn from others. All that is left is to perfect your understanding.

5

Master

You have mastered this skill. There is nothing more to learn about it.

Skill Check

=

3d8[Boons,Banes] + Average of Ability Bonuses (Round Up) + Skill Bonus + Enchantment Bonus

Example: Rolling a Skill Check

Albert, our storied naval captain from a previous example, is faced with a dilemma. His ship is about to be imperilled by a storm, and his crew is looking to him to safely navigate out of the harbor. As a Master Cartographer, Albert taps into his extremely strong knowledge of long-distance travel. This will be a Challenging (DC 25) roll; Albert rolls his Skill check. Unluckily, Albert's dice total turn up 6, 4, and 7— a total of 17 and a far cry from the needed 25. However, Albert's ability score for Strength is quite high at 8, and his Dexterity is 6, so the average of the two abilities adds an Ability bonus of 7. Albert also happens to have a magical set of nautical charts which grant a +2 enchantment bonus, pushing the result of the roll to 26.

Passive Skill Checks

Crucible allows any skill check to be considered passive at the discretion of the gamemaster. In a case where a character's trained skill rank is sufficient to exceed the DC of a roll by adding 12 to it, the check is considered successful without a need to roll.

Group Skill Checks

Crucible's handling of Group Skill Checks is a work in progress at this time, please look forward to a future update that adds this functionality.

Conditions Overview.name: Conditions Overview
Conditions Overview.text:
Conditions are temporary status effects which apply to a character. These conditions modify what actions the character can take, its resource pools, or the way that certain rules are applied to that character. This page separates Conditions into two categories; Statuses which describe the character's state of being and Damage-Over-Time which are detrimental or ameliorating effects which apply at the beginning of the character's Turn in Combat.

Damage Over Time

Some types of damage deal additional delayed damage. These conditions cause damage (or healing) that occurs at the start of a character's turn.

Weakened.name: Weakened
Weakened.text:
A creature that is Weakened is vulnerable to taking deadly wounds. Protagonists become Weakened when they reach zero Health. Any further damage to Health taken while Weakened increases Wounds.

While a creature is Weakened, it suffers -1 to maximum Action, loses access to a free Movement action, and suffers an additional 2 Vulnerability to any Morale damage sustained.

Dead.name: Dead
Dead.text: When a protagonist's Wounds reach their maximum value, or when an adversary's Health reaches zero, that character is Dead. A creature which is Dead is also treated as Incapacitated, can no longer Rest, and cannot be revived except by magical means.

Diseased.name: Diseased
Diseased.text: A creature that is Diseased cannot recover Health or heal Wounds for the duration of the Diseased effect.

Invulnerable.name: Invulnerable
Invulnerable.text: A creature that is Invulnerable is temporarily immune to Health or Wounds damage.

Broken.name: Broken
Broken.text:
A creature that is Broken is vulnerable to psychological trauma. Protagonists become Broken when they reach zero Morale. Any further damage to Morale taken while Broken increases Madness.

While a creature is Broken it cannot expend Focus, actions it takes suffer from +2 Banes, and it suffers an additional 2 Vulnerability to any Health damage sustained.

Creatures which are Broken cannot contribute towards Flanking. Non-player Adversaries which become Broken will attempt to flee the battle unless they lack instincts of self-preservation or escape seems impossible.

Insane.name: Insane
Insane.text: When a protagonist's Madness reaches its maximum value, that character is Insane. A character which is Insane may no longer be controlled by its player and is controlled by the Gamemaster. This condition cannot be healed or cured except by magical means.

Frightened.name: Frightened
Frightened.text: A creature that is Frightened cannot recover Morale or heal Madness for the duration of the Frightened effect.

Resolute.name: Resolute
Resolute.text: A creature which is Resolute is temporarily immune to Morale or Madness damage.

Enraged.name: Enraged
Enraged.text: When a creature is Enraged, it behaves recklessly and is less able to defend itself. An Enraged creature's Block and Parry defenses become zero and that creature cannot expend Focus.

Exposed.name: Exposed
Exposed.text: Some attacks can leave an enemy temporarily vulnerable. When a creature is Exposed attacks against it gain +2 Boons.

Flanked.name: Flanked
Flanked.text:
When a creature is Engaged by multiple foes which are its own size or larger and those foes are located on opposite sides of its square, the creature is considered to be Flanked.

When attacking a creature that is your size or smaller that is currently Flanked, you gain a number of Boons to Attack abilities equal to the number of flanking allies (excluding yourself).

Incapacitated.name: Incapacitated
Incapacitated.text: When a creature is entirely unable to act, it is Inacapacitated. When a target is Incapacitated, its Dodge, Block, and Parry defenses become zero and it no longer benefits from Ability Score bonuses to Fortitude, Willpower, or Reflex defense. It cannot contribute to Flanking or otherwise aid allies.

Prone.name: Prone
Prone.text: A creature that has been knocked to the ground, or has voluntarily thrown itself to the ground is considered Prone. While Prone, melee attacks against the target benefit from +1 Boon while ranged attacks against the target suffer from +1 Bane. Returning to your feet from a Prone position requires the use of a Movement action.

Staggered.name: Staggered
Staggered.text: A creature that is Staggered has their maximum Action reduced by 1.

Stunned.name: Stunned
Stunned.text: A creature that is Staggered has their maximum Action reduced by 2.

Paralyzed.name: Paralyzed
Paralyzed.text: A creature that is Paralyzed is unable to perform Actions until the paralysis is ended. During this time the target is Incapacitated.

Slowed.name: Slowed
Slowed.text: A creature that is Slowed treats distance as doubled for the purposes of determining the cost of the Move action. Additionally, a Slowed creature cannot benefit from a free Move.

Restrained.name: Restrained
Restrained.text: A creature that is Restrained is unable to perform any Action which involves Movement.

Disoriented.name: Disoriented
Disoriented.text: A creature that is Disoriented incurs a +1 Focus cost to all Actions which require Focus.

Guarded.name: Guarded
Guarded.text: Some terrain or abilities may temporarily harden a creature's defenses. When a creature is Guarded attacks against it suffer +1 Banes.

Unaware.name: Unaware
Unaware.text: A creature that is Unaware acts in combat at Initiative 1 and cannot perform Reactions.

Bleeding.name: Bleeding
Bleeding.text: A Bleeding creature suffers additional Piercing or Slashing damage, depending on the triggering damage type, at the start of its subsequent turns.

Poisoned.name: Poisoned
Poisoned.text: A Poisoned creature suffers additional Poison damage at the start of its subsequent turns.

Corroding.name: Corroding
Corroding.text: A Corroding creature suffers additional Acid damage at the start of its subsequent turns.

Burning.name: Burning
Burning.text: A Burning creature suffers additional Fire damage at the start of its subsequent turns.

Freezing.name: Freezing
Freezing.text: A Freezing creature suffers additional Cold damage at the start of its subsequent turns.

Irradiated.name: Irradiated
Irradiated.text: An Irradiated creature suffers additional Radiant damage at the start of its subsequent turns.

Decaying.name: Decaying
Decaying.text: A Decaying creature suffers additional Corruption damage at the start of its subsequent turns.

Hastened.name: Hastened
Hastened.text: A creature that is Hastened treats distance as halved for the purposes of determining the cost of the Move action. Additionally, a creature that is Hastened has +1 maximum Action available each turn.

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.text: A creature that is Blinded may not see using light-based perception and cannot use any Action which requires the target to be seen.

Deafened.name: Deafened
Deafened.text:
A creature which is Deafened is unable to utilize any sound-based perception and cannot be affected by any action with the Vocal trait.

TODO: Implementation of the Vocal trait still to come.

Silenced.name: Silenced
Silenced.text: A creature which is Silenced is unable to perform any action with the Vocal trait or to cast a Spell which includes a metamagic Inflection.

Invisible.name: Invisible
Invisible.text:
A creature which is Inivisible cannot be detected using sight-based perception.

TODO: More advanced rules for invisibility still to come.

Asleep.name: Asleep
Asleep.text: A creature that is Asleep is treated as incapacitated. Any damage to Health or Wounds causes it to immediately awaken. The creature is immune to Morale damage while sleeping unless otherwise stated.

Shocked.name: Shocked
Shocked.text: A Shocked creature suffers Electricity damage to Morale at the start of each turn.

Exhausted.name: Exhausted
Exhausted.text: A creature that is Exhausted can no longer actively defend itself. It's Dodge and Reflex defenses are reduced by half.

Alchemy.name: Alchemy
Alchemy.text:
Alchemy is the scientific practice of combining ingredients such as botanicals and minerals in order to produce consumable medicines, poisons, and explosives through zymurgy, distillation, or homogenization.

An alchemist can combine commonly available ingredients to produce consumable potions such as@UUID[Compendium.crucible.equipment.Item.healingTonic0000]{Healing Tonic} or @UUID[Compendium.crucible.equipment.Item.poisonVial000000]{Poison Vial}, as well as throwable weapons such as @UUID[Compendium.crucible.equipment.Item.KdlUUFhAnpv6YIHT]{Blast Flask}.

Enchanting.name: Enchanting
Enchanting.text:
Enchanting is the art of combining existing Glyphs (created by @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.crucibleCrafting.JournalEntryPage.runeweaving00000]{Runeweavers}) with equipment created by other crafters (such as @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.crucibleCrafting.JournalEntryPage.smithing00000000]{Smiths}, @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.crucibleCrafting.JournalEntryPage.tailoring0000000]{Tailors}, and @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.crucibleCrafting.JournalEntryPage.jewelcraft000000]{Jewelcrafters}) in order to imbue those items with permanent magical properties. The process of enchanting an item typically involves some additional sympathetic material components which are used in a ritual to bind the magical effect to a non-magical item, typically one of at least Fine quality.

Fletching.text:
Fletching is the skill of combining commonly available components such as wood, leather, plant fibers and feathers to create bows and ammunition. A Fletcher is capable of crafting and repairing bows, and ensuring that they don't run out of suitable supply of arrows.

Jewelcraft.text:

Runeweaving.name: Runeweaving

Runeweaving is the arcane science of inscribing physical manifestations of metaphysical @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.qjTSKlh59JhtUuEr.JournalEntryPage.p3hKRiZN3x0DEtyG]{Runes} to create Glyphs.
