Schematics.name: Schematics
Schematics.text:
Schematics are items in Crucible which define the rules by which input items (often called "ingredients") are transformed into output items (often called "products") using the crafting system and its set of Trades@UUID[.tradeskillsOverv]{Tradeskills}.

Schematic Definition

Schematics have the following components:

Category

The category of a schematic defines which Tradeskill is required to manufacture it.

Inputs

Schematic inputs define a set of ingredients which are required in order to manufacture it. Ingredients can be specified in groups, with each group having a specific mode that customizes whether all ingredients in that group are required or only one of several options.

Additionally, each input group can require a certain amount of currency which represents minor ingredients or supplies inherent in the crafting attempt which are not individually enumerated as ingredient items.

Lastly, each input group specifies whether the ingredients in that group are consumed in the process of crafting or not. Note that even ingredients which are not ordinarily consumed during the process of crafting can become broken if the attempt results in a critical failure.

Outputs

Schematic outputs define the products which result from successful manufacturing of the schematic. A schematic can produce one or multiple outputs. In the event that multiple outputs are produced, the schematic can configure whether all of the outputs are obtained or only one of them.

If only one output is obtained, the schematic must define a number of alternative input groups which maps to the number of potential products. The input group used during crafting determines which product is obtained.

Quality

Schematics have a quality which defines the initial quality of outputs resulting from manufacture of the schematic. The final quality of outputs is also determined by the quality of ingredients used as well as the success tier on the corresponding crafting check.

Difficulty

Schematics define a difficulty threshold (DC) which specifies the value that a crafting check must exceed in order to result in a successful outcome.

Hours

Schematics specify the number of hours required to complete manufacture. These hours must be performed consecutively without interruption. For especially long-duration crafting endeavors any amount of required resting time should be included in this number.

Obtaining Schematics

Schematics are generally obtained during the course of adventure by finding them within the world or obtaining them from other characters. Each schematic, like all physical items, has a base price which is further scaled according to its quality level. This price is used when purchasing or selling schematics in trade with non-player characters.

There are a number of schematics provided by the core Crucible system. These system-provided schematics can be found in the Crucible ➤ Items ➤ Schematics compendium pack.

Gamemasters can define their own schematics which can be awarded to characters directly or placed into an ancillary compendium pack which makes them available for use in crafting.

Custom compendium packs of schematics can be assigned under Configure Settings ➤ Crucible ➤ Configure Compendium Sources.

Learning Schematics

Schematics provide detailed instructions for the creation process of their outputs. Manufacturing an item requires the crafter to either physically possess the schematic, have mastered it, or for the schematic to be classified as "common knowledge".

Schematics are mastered by completing their crafting process with a result of a critical success. Once a schematic has been mastered it is no longer physically required in order to repeat its process.

Crafting in Crucible is performed using a set of Tradeskills which, similar to adventuring @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.skills0000000000]{Skills}, are invested aspects of your character's identity obtained through @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.talents000000000]{Talent} progression and through the accumulation of knowledge in the form of @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.crucibleCrafting.JournalEntryPage.schematicDefinit]{Schematics}.

Weapons.name: Weapons
Weapons.text:
Weapons are a specific Item type which represents items that are wielded in a character's hands and used in combat. The Crucible system provides the basic rules for creating and classifying weapons, and also provides an array of pre-defined weapon types which are typically observed in a fantasy role-playing game. These weapons can be browsed in the Weapons Compendium pack.

Weapons all have the following attributes, in addition to those shared by all items:

Category

The category of a weapon establishes certain parameters about how that weapon may be used. How many hands does it require to wield? Is it a melee weapon or a ranged weapon? Does it require ammunition? Which ability scores modify its usage? And more. The possible weapon categories are listed in the table below.

Broken Weapons

During the course of use, or over the passage of time, weapons may become Broken. Weapons which are Broken deal half their normal damage and cannot contribute to Block or Parry defenses. Repairing a Broken weapon restores it to its original quality tier or a lesser quality tier depending on the result of the Tradecraft skill check to repair the weapon.

Enchantment Tier

Enchantment of a Weapon describes its level of magical imbuement. Enchantment tiers provide an additional bonus to attack rolls of the weapon and contribute towards its Rarity score.

Special Properties

Some weapons may have one (or in very rare cases multiple) of the following special properties. Each of these properties adds a +1 Rarity modifier to the weapon.

Several of the following properties, denoted with an * after their name, are not yet fully automated in the first Crucible Playtest system yet.

Oversized

This weapon is large for its category and is unwieldy in combat without special training. The weapon gains an additional +2 bonus to base damage but is slow and provides +2 Banes to Initiative rolls.

Reach

This weapon is lengthy and offers an expanded attack range. The range of melee weapons is increased by +2 feet. Ranged weapons are expanded by +20 feet.

Parrying

This weapon provides a bonus to Parry defense while equipped and not Broken. The bonus is +1 for one-handed weapons and +2 for two-handed weapons, plus the enchantment bonus of the weapon.

Blocking

This weapon provides a bonus to Block defense while equipped and not Broken. The bonus is +1 for one-handed weapons and +2 for two-handed weapons, plus the enchantment bonus of the weapon.

Versatile*

This normally one-handed weapon can be used effectively with two hands. While equipped without any item in the off-hand its base damage is increased by +2 and Action cost is increased by +1.

Thrown*

This weapon can be used to Strike at range up to a distance of 20 feet. When used to Strike a target that is not within melee range, the Weapon becomes unequipped and must be retrieved before it can be used again.

Keen

This weapon is capable of achieving particularly deadly strikes. The critical hit threshold of the weapon is reduced by 2 making it more likely that successful Strikes yield a critical hit.

Reliable

This weapon is trustworthy and almost never produces spectacularly bad outcomes. The critical failure threshold of the weapon is reduced by 2 making it less likely that unsuccessful Strikes yield a critical miss.

Ambush

This weapon can be easily concealed and retrieved quickly. This weapon may be drawn for free during your own turn or as part of a Reaction.

Engaging

This weapon is designed to better allow you to combat multiple foes, increasing your Engagement by +1.

Equipment Overview.name: Equipment Overview
Equipment Overview.text:
Equipment refers to the belongings, weaponry, armor, potions, adventuring equipment, and other types of items which could be carried by a character or found somewhere within the world.

Equipment types share a few properties in common across all types:

Weight

Each item has a per-unit weight, expressed in pounds.

Base Cost

The base cost of an item establishes the basis for any cost scaling which later applies. For some items the base cost and scaled cost are always the same, but some items can have a true value many times greater than the item's base cost.

Physical Quality

Many items may be assigned a quality tier which reflects the manufacturing quality or natural rarity of a certain commodity.

Enchantment Tier

Items which can be augmented with magic have an enchantment tier which reflects the potency of magic that is imbued into the item.

Rarity

Item rarity quantifies the uniqueness of the item relative to it's most common form. Items with higher manufactured quality, stronger magical enchantment, or rare properties will have a higher rarity value and therefore a greater value.

Item Value Scaling

The base cost of a weapon is defined by its Standard quality, Mundane enchantment variety. The currency cost of the weapon scales with its Rarity score according to the following formula:

Item Value

=

(1 + (Rarity^3) × Base Cost

Suppose a Standard quality and unenchanted Mundane Longsword has a base cost of 50. The same type of weapon crafted at Masterwork quality would cost 3200. If a Legendary enchantment were added to the weapon, it would then cost 25,650. A true fortune!

Armor.name: Armor
Armor.text:
Armor are items which can be worn to provide @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Defenses00000000]{Physical Defense} against attacks or environmental hazards. The Crucible system provides a framework and rules for creating and classifying Armor, and also provides an assortment of predefined Armor types which are typical to a fantasy role-playing setting. These Armors can be browsed in the Armor Compendium pack.

Armor Categories

The category of armor establishes certain parameters about how that armor is used. What is it's weight category? How much physical protection does it afford? How capable of nimble movement is someone while wearing it? Supported Armor categories are listed in a table below. The following table lists the categories of Armor supported in the Crucible game system.

Armor CategoryBase ArmorBase DodgeScaling Threshold

Light4-86-84 Dex

Heavy14-180-28 Dex

The total Physical Defense contributed by the piece of Armor is equal to the sum of Armor and Dodge components.

Physical Defense

=

Base Armor + Bonus Armor + Base Dodge + Bonus Dodge

@UUID[Compendium.crucible.equipment.Item.scaleMail0000000]{Scale Mail} is Medium Armor which offers 13 Armor Defense and 3 Base Dodge Defense. As Medium Armor, the effectiveness of Scale Mail will continue to improve if the wearer has more than 6 Dexterity, it's Scaling Threshold. When Jex, a nimble fighter with 8 Dexterity, dons Scale Mail armor they benefit from a total Physical Defense of 18 (13 Armor + 5 Dodge).

When Jex returns to the city from adventuring, they purchase a Fine Quality set of Scale Mail with a Minor Enchantment. Jex' total Physical Defense improves to 20 (14 Armor + 6 Dodge).

Wearing Heavy Armor does not permit a free Move action each turn as other armor types do unless the character has a specific Talent which negates this penalty.

Armor Defense

Each piece of Armor provides a certain amount of Base Armor defense, bounded by the range allowed by its category. This Armor defense contributes directly towards Physical Defense when the item is equipped. In addition to Base Armor, the piece of armor may offer Bonus Armor according to its Quality tier which is described below.

Dodge Defense

Each piece of Armor provides a baseline amount of Dodge defense. The amount of base dodge defense provided by the armor is defined according to a formula specific to its category.

Base Dodge (Light)

=

10 - (Base Armor / 2)

Base Dodge (Medium)

=

10 - ((Base Armor-1) / 2)

Base Dodge (Heavy)

=

10 - ((Base Armor-2) / 2)

Base Dodge (Natural)

=

10 - (Base Armor / 2)

In addition to Base Dodge defense, each piece of Armor can yield additional Bonus Dodge defense depending on the wearer's Dexterity ability score exceeds a certain Dodge Scaling Threshold. Bonus Dodge is also increased by the item's Enchantment Tier which is described below.

Bonus Dodge

=

Max(Dexterity - Scaling Threshold, 0) + Enchantment Bonus

Quality Tier

Quality of Armor describes its craftsmanship, materials, and condition. Quality tiers provide an additional bonus to Armor defense and increase item rarity. The quality tier of Armor is established at its time of initial creation and can never be increased after that point.

During the course of use, or over the passage of time, Armor may become Broken. Armor which is Broken only benefits from half its normal Armor Defense.

Special Properties

Some Armor may have one (or in very rare cases multiple) of the following special properties. Each of these properties adds a +1 Rarity modifier to the Armor.

Bulky

Armor that is Bulky is cumbersome to wield and conveys a penalty of +2 Banes to all Initiative rolls.

Ancestry.name: Ancestry
Ancestry.text:
The first step in character creation is selecting an @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.ancestry00000000], which classifies the biology and physiology of a character in Crucible, and grants the newly created hero specific starting traits.

You can change your character's Ancestry at any point during the character creation, but be aware that doing so may impact your currently assigned Ability Scores if you have already chosen them and that may require re-selecting them before completing your character creation.

While Crucible provides a number of example ancestries, it also allows use of custom ancestries by providing a way for GMs to configure their own compendium packs to use as a source during character creation. To add your compendium as a source, go to Configure Settings ➤ Crucible ➤ Configure Compendium Sources.

Ancestry Features

Each Ancestry includes:

  • A Primary Ability Score (which begins at 3)

  • A Secondary Ability Score (which begins at 2)

  • Optionally, a Damage Resistance (+3) and a Damage Vulnerability (-3).

  • A Size value in grid spaces (typically 4)

  • A Stride value in grid spaces that determines the starting movement speed (typically 10)

  • An Ancestral Talent which grants a specific special ability or knowledge to a character of that ancestry.

Currently, the built-in Ancestries which are provided with the Crucible system do not have unique starting talents. Unique talents for these built-in ancestries will be added in a future update.

Background and Ability Scores.name: Background and Ability Scores
Background and Ability Scores.text:
Each character chooses a @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.backgrounds00000]{Background} which reflects a hero's cultural upbringing, professional training, career to date, or other aspects of their past before the advent of the campaign's storyline. Your choice of Background further augments your character.

Background Features

Each Background includes:

  • Novice Skills (typically 2)

  • Knowledge Areas (typically 2)

  • Known Languages

  • Starting Talents (typically 2, one of which is training talent)

While Crucible provides a number of example backgrounds, it also allows use of custom backgrounds by providing a way for GMs to configure their own compendium packs to use as a source during character creation. To add your compendium as a source, go to Configure Settings ➤ Crucible ➤ Configure Compendium Sources.

Ability Scores

After you have selected your background, it is time to allocate Ability Points to determine your character's starting @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.abilityScores000]{Ability Scores}.

Each Ancestry provides a Primary Ability Score which begins at 3, and a Secondary Ability Score which begins at 2. All other ability scores begin at 1. The values of each Ability Score range from 1 to 12, where the typical value of this attribute for a non-remarkable Human is 2.

In addition to starting Ability Score values provided by your Ancestry, each character begins with 9 Ability Points which can be allocated towards any of the six Ability Scores. To spend Ability Points click the up or down arrows to the right of the desired Ability.

You may only increase a single Ability Score a maximum of 3 times during character creation. A counter at the top of the Ability Scores section displays how many points you have remaining to spend.

Once you have completed character creation and advanced your character to Level 1 the starting Ability Scores which you purchased can no longer be changed, but these ability scores may still be increased over time as you continue to level up.

Overview.name: Overview
Overview.text:
This chapter of the rules guides Gamemasters and Players through the process of creating their characters and preparing for play.

Creating a Party

Begin setting up a game in Crucible by creating a Party which the player characters can all belong to by creating an Actor with the Group type. As players create their heroes, add them to the Party by dragging-and-dropping them onto the Party sheet.

Once you have created a Party, you should also configure this group as the "Primary Adventuring Party" under Game Settings ➤ Crucible ➤ Primary Adventuring Party. Taking this step allows a large number of mechanics to be automated which depend on knowing which group is the party of active Heroes.

Creating Heroes

Heroes are the characters in Crucible which are controlled and portrayed by players, also known as "player characters". All Heroes, even those at Level 1, are capable adventurers. They are smart, charismatic, athletic, and skillful - but not yet to a degree that is wondrous. As characters advance in level they attain tiers of power where their physical, mental, and social capabilities are truly legendary. Character advancement in Crucible is level-based. Increases in level grant additional Ability, Skill, and Talent points to spend which increase a character's power and capabilities. The maximum character level in Crucible is anticipated to be 18.

Character creation is an easy process which begins by creating a New Actor of the Hero type. Creating a character is a guided process with a unique interface that walks you through the process step-by-step. You may reset the character creation process at any time by clicking the "restart" button located at the top right of the character creation screen.

Starting Level

If organizing a gameplay experience that seeks to tell the origin story of heroes, starting your game at Level 1 is the recommended choice. If, however, you want to jump into an adventure with characters who are already established champions, beginning at a higher level may be more suitable.

If starting at a higher level than 1, we recommend each player prepare a set of short anecdotes which explain the skill and talent advancements that their character has unlocked prior to the start of the game. This process helps to solidify their character backstory through past events that explain their heroic capabilities.

Review the pages in this journal entry to understand the steps of character creation and the choices you will make during that process.

Level Advancement.name: Level Advancement
Level Advancement.text:
Each time you gain a character Level beyond 1 you can further advance your character's powers and capabilities. Each additional level grants you:

  • 1 Ability Point which can increase one of your Ability scores by one.
  • 2 Talent Points which can be used to purchase new character Talents.

After gaining a level you should take a moment to invest these points so that you are prepared to face more challenging and heroic tasks.

Leveling up occurs when your party has accomplished a certain number of Milestones. Milestones are structured around the completion of strategic objectives, the arrival of significant plot moments, or the vanquishing of notable foes.

Crucible facilitates the convenient marking of milestones through the Group Actor sheet, which allows the GM to add group members to the sheet by dragging them from the Actor sidebar. After a group has been formed, clicking the center of the hex for Milestones Earned raises an award prompt, allowing the GM to quickly add an identified milestone, amount of award, and reason for the milestone being awarded. When awarding a milestone through this method, the GM may also selectively grant the milestone only to particular group members.

Leveling Up

Milestones earned apply to the entire party, even if certain characters or players were not present when the milestone was achieved. When reaching the number of milestones required to level-up, the entire party has the capability to advance in Level.

Advancing your Level happens during a Rest action, at which point each member of the party may increase their level by one, invest their granted ability point to progress their @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.abilityScores000]{Ability Scores}, and spend additional @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.talents000000000]{Talent} points.

Talents.name: Talents
Talents.text:
@UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.talents000000000] are unique abilities or skills that your character has gained over the course of their life, and as the game progresses are expanded upon as you gain levels.

In addition to the talents you gained when you selected an Ancestry and Background, each new character has 3 initial Talent points which can be used to select unique Skills and Abilities. Talents are a roadmap for your character's development, allowing you to invest into unique paths that provide powerful abilities.

After you have chosen your talents, the "Complete" button will appear in the top right of the character creation window. After you have completed creation, your character is complete and your selections are final, and your newly created Actor Sheet will open.

Finishing Touches.name: Finishing Touches
Finishing Touches.text:
While character creation is technically finished once the "Complete" button has been pressed, there are a few details you may wish to add to your character.

In the User Configuration menu you can set your configure your newly created Hero as your Player Character, which will allow the game to automatically choose that character for certain aspects of automation. For example, you can press the C key to quickly open your character sheet!

Starting Equipment

Choosing starting equipment is an important part of beginning any adventure. We advise Gamemasters to work closely with their players to determine what basic equipment they feel is appropriate for each character by browsing the existing Equipment compendium (found on the compendium tab in the Items folder). Dragging items from this compendium onto your newly created Actor Sheet will assign the item to that Actor's Inventory.

A newly created character begins their journey with [[/award 250gp]] which is automatically added to their inventory. You may spend this initial budget on starting equipment. As you purchase initial equipment, deduct the full Scaled Price of each item from your initial gold allowance.

We anticipate that a guided experience to spending your starting gold budget on initial items may be added as a Character Creation step in the future!

It is important that when adding character equipment you mark anything that the character is wearing as equipped by clicking on the Equip button on the right hand side of the sheet next to the edit and delete buttons.

Gamemasters can create and use their own custom Items either through the sidebar tab (for items that will be used by many characters) or by clicking the + icon on the bottom right corner of any Actor's inventory tab for more unique, character-specific items.

Appearance and Details

With character creation finished, it's a good idea to choose a picture to represent your character by clicking on the icon of the hooded figure on the upper left corner of the actor sheet. In addition, on the Biography tab, you can fill in some important details such as Pronouns, Age, Height, Weight, and provide a physical description to accompany your hero.

Biographies

As a final piece of character creation, you might wish to provide a Public Biography that other players in your game will be able to see, containing some facts about your hero's reputation and history. Any details in the Private Biography section will only be shown to you and your gamemaster, making it a useful place to write your hero's complete backstory.

Spellcraft Overview.name: Spellcraft Overview
Spellcraft Overview.text:
Spellcraft is the particular art and theory of magic as implemented in the Crucible system. Proficiecy with spellcraft advances through Talents that are learned as part of character progression. The Crucible spellcraft system is designed to be dynamic and generative, allowing players who wish to focus their character on spellcasting to improvise and discover effective combinations and applications for their magical abilities.

The Spellcraft system is still a work-in-progress and, while functional, is expected to undergo substantial revision and iteration in future Crucible releases. The implementation of the Spellcraft system in Playtest One should provide insight into its mechanics and planned functionality.

Masterful Composition

Spellcraft allows characters to manifest magic by composing a spell using a @UUID[.p3hKRiZN3x0DEtyG]{Rune}, @UUID[.lhrYInsQ2f0YfhTu]{Gesture}, and optionally an @UUID[.ELOcfx6LPZMh74y8]{Inflection}.

  • Runes represent the base magical essence (such as Spirit or Flame), metaphysical concepts that combine to form the laws of reality.

  • Gestures represent the forming of the rune into a spell, using physical motion as a somatic component which shape (such as Create or Arrow) a Rune's power, causing it to act in a specific way.

  • Inflections represent a further change or modification (such as Quicken or Pull), and use vocalization to alter how a spell is formed.

As your character learns Talents which provide Spellcraft components, these components will appear on the Grimoire tab of your character sheet and become usable through the Cast a Spell action. The process of learning components and discovering new spell combinations is intended to provide a rewarding experience of magical experimentation and narrative development for characters which invest into Spellcraft.

It is useful to think of the rules and structure of the Spellcraft system linguistically. If you think of a spell as a sentence, each spell must have a Rune (noun) and a Gesture (verb), and may optionally include an Inflection (adjective/adverb) that modifies either.

Spells which attack an opponent follow the rules of @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.QhZgmBrdLAGwYy5c.JournalEntryPage.lZfPVvBSsCEqlte4]{Attack Rolls}, with changes to the Ability Bonus and Base Damage of the attack depending on the combination of Rune and Gesture used.

Example: Zarajah the Pyromancer

Zarajah is an ambitious Level 6 sorcerer who strives to master the arts of elemental magic. Zarajah knows the runes for Flame, Kinesis, and Lightning as well as gestures for Touch (automatically learned), Influence, and Arrow. Additionally, Zarajah has also learned the Quicken inflection. Using these components, Zarajah has access to 18 different combinations which form Spells.

Zarajah's favorite spell is Quickened Arrow of Flame which allows her to hurl a projectile of arcane fire at a single target up to 10 spaces distant at the cost of 1 Action and 2 Focus points. The Flame rune targets Reflex defense and deals Fire Damage to Health. Arrow and Flame both scale using Intellect, so the effectiveness of this spell scales using only Intellect as a single ability score.

When Zarajah casts a Quickened Arrow of Flame towards a swooping Manticore, she rolls a 28 on her spell attack roll, beating the Manticore's Reflex defense of 21. This 7 Overflow Damage is increased by the 10 Base Damage of the Arrow gesture, resulting in a total of 17 Fire Damage dealt to the foe.

Since this attack is also a Critical Hit, the Manticore bursts into flame due to Zarajah's Pyromancer talent which inflicts the Burning condition causing additional damage-over-time.

The Cost of Magic

Every magic spell has a cost- whether used within a combat situation or for out-of-combat benefits. Generally, this cost is paid in the form of @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Resources0000000#capacity-for-action]{Focus Points}, though in some situations the cost may use other resources or have other requirements.

As you construct your spells, the cost of the spell in Action Points and Focus Points may change based on your choice of @UUID[.p3hKRiZN3x0DEtyG]{Rune}, @UUID[.lhrYInsQ2f0YfhTu]{Gesture} and @UUID[.ELOcfx6LPZMh74y8]{Inflection}.

Runes.name: Runes
Runes.text:
Runes are the most basic metaphysical concept of magic. They are forces of nature, the building blocks of reality as we understand it. Understanding the Runes and their place in the way the world functions allows those with sufficient training to exert a level of influence over the Runes, using @UUID[.lhrYInsQ2f0YfhTu]{Gestures} to manifest powerful displays of magical prowess.

There are six Chaotic Runes and six Orderly Runes, forming a natural opposition to one another.

Gestures.name: Gestures
Gestures.text:
Gestures are the physical, somatic components required to invoke a rune for Spellcraft purposes. Gestures determine the shape a spell will take as it is translated from the raw magical energies governed by a Rune into a manifestation of that power. Gestures set particular properties of a magical spell, usually the cost in Action and Focus points, range (or size), targeting type, and shape. Gestures also determine one-half of the scaling damage formula, with Rune as the other half.

Starting Gesture

Any spellcaster who knows any Rune automatically has access to the Touch gesture which provides a basic capability to use that Rune. More advanced usages of that Rune require incorporating more advanced Gestures.

Touch

You empower the arcane energy of a Rune into a hand-to-hand attack. The Touch gesture scales using Dexterity and targets a single creature at a range of 1 foot, dealing 6 Base Damage to targets which fail to Resist the spell. This gesture requires 1 Hand to cast and has a base cost of 2 Action and 1 Focus.

Tier 1 Gestures

Tier 1 gestures (character levels 1-5) provide wide-ranging fundamentals of spellcraft composition that allows shaping Runes into a variety of offensive or defensive forms.

Arrow

You hurl a projectile imbued with the magical power of a Rune at a distant target. The Arrow gesture scales using Intellect and targets a single creature up to a distance of 60 feet, dealing 8 Base Damage to targets which fail to Resist the spell. This gesture requires 1 Hand to cast and has a base cost of 3 Action and 1 Focus.

Aspect

You infuse the essence of a Rune into your body, empowering your own physical form or psyche. When you assume a certain Aspect, you become more closely attuned to the damage type of the Rune used in your spell. You gain +2 Resistance to that damage type, and deal an additional +2 Damage whenever dealing damage of that type. Your Aspect lasts for 6 Rounds. You may only have one active Aspect, casting another spell using the Aspect gesture replaces the previous effect. This gesture requires 1 Hand to cast and has a base cost of 2 Action and 1 Focus.

Create

You coalesce arcane power into tangible form, manifesting a Sprite which appears within 10 feet and joins Combat at Initiative 1. Your Sprite is a Minion of half your own Level. The Create gesture scales with Wisdom and the Sprite survives for 6 Rounds. You may only have one active Sprite, casting another spell using the Create gesture replaces your previous Sprite. This gesture requires 2 Hands to cast and has a base cost of 4 Action and 1 Focus.

Fan

You shape the essence of a Rune into a sweeping or splintered arc to strike multiple targets in close proximity. The Fan gesture scales using Intellect and targets a 120 degree arc with 6 foot radius. It deals 6 Base Damage to targets which fail to Resist the spell. This gesture requires 1 Hand to cast and has a base cost of 3 Action and 1 Focus.

Influence

You intensify the arcane power of a Rune into a concentrated direct contact which is generally a more powerful evolution of the basic Touch gesture. The Influence gesture scales using Presence and targets a single adjacent creature. It deals 10 Base Damage to targets which fail to Resist the spell. This gesture requires 1 Hand to cast and has a base cost of 3 Action and 1 Focus.

Ray

You funnel the arcane power of a Rune into a point and project it outwards in a beam. The Ray gesture scales using Wisdom and produces a line that is 1 foot wide and 30 feet long originating from the spellcaster, dealing 6 Base Damage to targets which fail to Resist the spell. The gesture requires 1 Hand to cast and has a base cost of 4 Action and 1 Focus.

Sense

You attune your mind to the arcane power of a Rune to sense nearby sources of energy. The Sense gesture scales with Presence and produces an emanation with 30 feet radius and position that remains centered upon the spellcaster. This gesture requires 1 Hand to cast and has a base cost of 3 Action and 1 Focus. It may optionally be Maintained at the additional cost of 1 Focus every subsequent round.

This spell allows the caster to detect the presence of spellcraft using the same Rune as the one incorporated in this spell. The sense will also momentarily detect the presence of creatures according to their type.

  • Control: Fiends

  • Death: Undead

  • Earth: Oozes and Earth Elementals

  • Flame: Dragons and Fire Elementals

  • Frost: Giants and Frost Elementals

  • Illumination: Celestials

  • Illusion: Fey

  • Kinesis: Monstrosities

  • Life: Plants and Beasts

  • Lightning: Constructs and Storm Elementals

  • Oblivion: Outsiders

  • Soul: Humanoids

Step

You infuse runic power into a movement, crossing physical and spatial boundaries. The Step gesture scales with Dexterity and allows you to move up to 20 feet in a straight line with width equal to your Size. It deals 2 Base Damage to targets along that line which fail to Resist the spell. This gesture does not require any free hands to cast and has a base cost of 3 Action and 1 Focus.

Strike

You empower a direct close-range attack with the arcane essence of a Rune, performing a Strike with your equipped weapon. The Strike gesture scales using Strength and deal damage based on your used weapon but with the damage type of the incorporated Rune. This gesture does not require any free hand and has a base cost of 1 Focus in addition to the cost of your weapon Strike.

Ward

You shape the arcane power of a Rune into a protective barrier used to shield yourself from harm. The Ward gesture scales using Toughness and provides +6 Resistance against the damage type of the Rune used in the spell. This resistance lasts for 1 Round and you may only have a single Ward at a time. Casting another spell using the Ward gesture replaces your prior Ward. This gesture requires 1 Hand to cast and has a base cost of 2 Action and 1 Focus.

Tier 2 Gestures

Tier 2 gestures (character levels 6-11) provide advanced capabilities that improve or expand upon fundamental Tier 1 gestures.

Aura

You concentrate the arcane power of a Rune to create a maintained field of energy that washes over allies and enemies near to you. The Aura gesture scales with Presence and produces an emanation with 20 feet radius centered on the spellcaster. The center of this Aura moves with the spellcaster. Depending on the Rune used, the Aura deals damage or provides healing to any creature which begins its turn inside the Aura. This gesture requires 2 Hands to cast, has a base cost of 5 Action and 1 Focus, and must be Maintained costing an additional 1 Focus every subsequent round.

Blast

You hurl the arcane power of a Rune into an intense explosion of energy at a nearby point you can see. The Blast gesture scales with Intellect and produces a blast with 6 feet radius centered on a point within 60 feet of the spellcaster. The blast deals 8 Base Damage to targets which fail to Resist the spell. This gesture requires 2 Hands to cast and has a base cost of 5 Action and 2 Focus.

Cone

You focus the arcane power of a Rune into a narrow cone that projects outwards from your location. The Cone gesture scales with Intellect and produces a 60 degree cone with a 30 foot radius originating from the spellcaster. The Cone deals 8 Base Damage to targets which fail to Resist the spell. This gesture requires 2 Hands to cast and has a base cost of 5 Action and 2 Focus.

Conjure

You coalesce arcane power into a superior form, manifesting a Visitor which appears within 30 feet and joins Combat at Initiative 1. Your Visitor is a Minion equal to your own Level. The Conjure gesture scales with Wisdom and the Visitor survives for 12 Rounds. You may only have one active Visitor. Casting another spell using the Conjure gesture replaces your previous Visitor. This gesture requires 2 Hands to cast and has a base cost of 5 Action and 2 Focus.

Pulse

Expel the arcane power of a Rune in a radius that travels outward with you at its center. The Pulse gesture scales using Presence and produces an emanation with 10 foot radius, dealing 8 Base Damage to targets which fail to Resist the spell. The gesture requires 2 Hands to cast and has a base cost of 5 Action and 2 Focus.

Surge

Expel the arcane power of a Rune in a radius that travels outward with you at its center. The Pulse gesture scales using Presence and produces an emanation with 10 foot radius, dealing 8 Base Damage to targets which fail to Resist the spell. The gesture requires 2 Hands to cast and has a base cost of 5 Action and 2 Focus.

Iconic Spells.name: Iconic Spells
Iconic Spells.text:
In addition to Composed Spells, investment into spellcraft talents unlocks Iconic Spell slots which provide a limited number of special spells which you know. These Iconic Spells have specialized effects which are not otherwise possible via the Composed Spell system and cover the breadth of magical capability that a system like Crucible requires.

Learning Iconic Spells

Each character has a certain number of Iconic Spell slots — initially zero. When learning certain spellcraft talents, you will gain an additional Iconic Spell slot which can then be populated with an Iconic Spell provided you possess the prerequisite knowledge to learn it.

Replacing Iconic Spells

When your character advances in level you may — if you wish — remove one known Iconic Spell from your repetoire, freeing that spell slot to be filled with an alternative Iconic Spell.

Countermagic.name: Countermagic
Countermagic.text:
Countermagic is the art of magical defence, weaving opposing spellcraft to negate the spell being cast by an opponent. Constructing a proper counterspell requires a degree of magical knowledge and an ability to process that knowledge in an asymmetric way, as you may not always have all the information needed to build your opposition correctly. Someone with a deep understanding of magic may be able to easily identify the telltale signs of specific Runes being used, identify a gesture, or interpret an inflection and glean the purpose of a spell. Someone practiced in Countermagic may find unique ways to disrupt a spell being cast, including sapping the magical energies from it at inception.

The Counterspell sub-system has not been included in this playtest.

Overview.name: Overview
Overview.text:
Adversaries in Crucible are the non-player characters which populate and inhabit the world. Despite the name, not all adversaries are antagonistic in nature, we simply use the term "Adversary" to refer to non-player actors in the system.

Adversaries share most mechanical concepts in common with @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.gszlBVQ5fGh3y0I6.JournalEntryPage.DjePpoV2oJenlyTf]{Overview} (player characters) including Ability Scores, Resources, Defenses, Skills, Resistances, and Talents, but adversaries progress somewhat differently than player characters.

Threat Level describes the degree of mechanical challenge posed by a certain Adversary and is defined by the product of Level and Threat Category. An adversaries attributes and difficulty scale with higher level and higher Threat Category.

Threat Level

=

Level × Threat Multiplier

Threat Categories

Each Threat Category contributes a multiplier to the effective Threat Level of the Adversary and also determines the number of @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.QhZgmBrdLAGwYy5c.JournalEntryPage.2U2k8WcnB1gbPLfd]{Action Points} that the Adversary has in combat. The Threat Categories in the Crucible system are:

Threat CategoryThreat MultiplierAction PointsDescription
Minion× 0.52Weaker than average foes at a given level, minions are less dangerous and more easily dispatched - but may be numerous in quantity.

Normal

× 13The standard level of difficulty and challenge for a certain level.
Elite× 1.54Stronger than average foes at a given level, elites are more dangerous and more difficult to dispatch. Elites are more rarely encountered.
Boss× 25Especially dangerous enemies which represent the ultimate degree of challenge at a certain level. Most encounters do not contain a boss.

Attribute Scaling

Where Protagonists feature an Ancestry and Background, instead Adversaries use the concepts of @UUID[.qSeJNy28eK9axO7C]{Taxonomy} and @UUID[.O8IesdQo8SQpIKbo]{Archetype}, both of which define how the attributes of the Adversary progress as it increases in Threat Level.

Adversary Talents

Adversaries may be assigned additional Talents in addition to those automatically provided by their Archetype.

Eventually there may be some rules limiting the number and tier of Talents that an Adversary may have, but for the time being it is acceptable for Adversaries to have any talents that the Gamemaster wishes to give them in addition to the Talents automatically provided by their Archetype.

Defeating Adversaries

Adversaries do not have Wounds or Madness pools like Protagonist characters, instead their ability to withstand harm is determined entirely by Health and Morale.

When an Adversary Health pool reaches zero it becomes @Condition[dead] or, if preferred by the Gamemaster for narrative reasons, @Condition[incapacitated], and takes no further action during the encounter.

When Adversary Morale reaches zero it becomes @Condition[broken]. A Broken Adversary will attempt to flee the battlefield unless they lack instincts of self-preservation or the possibility of escape seems impossible - in which case they will continue to fight to the death.

Taxonomy.name: Taxonomy
Taxonomy.text:
Taxonomy classifies the biology of an Adversary in Crucible. Each Taxonomy defines a variety of basic properties:

  • Category (such as whether a creature is an Beast, Celestial, Humanoid, etc.)

  • Base size of an adversary (in grid spaces)

  • Stride (movement speed in feet)

  • Whether the creature can wear typical humanoid equipment or cast spells

  • @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.abilityScores000]{Abilities} which determine baseline attributes

  • @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.Resistances00000]{Resistances} and Immunities which define how damage resistances scale with threat level and whether the creature is immune to any specific types of damage.

  • Any talents that all creatures with this taxonomy should start with

Example: Hobgoblin Taxonomy

Hobgoblins are humanoids which typically congregate in martial societies which are orderly and disciplined. Hobgoblins are both cunning and uncompromising, making dangerous foes or powerful allies.

The Hobgoblin Taxonomy defines scaling weights such that Strength, Intellect, and Toughness evolve more frequently while Wisdom, Presence, and Dexterity evolve more slowly.

Many different Adversaries will use the same Taxonomy, for example a Level 3 Hobgoblin Archer, Level 4 Hobgoblin Fighter, and a Level 6 Hobgoblin Witch Doctor. Each of these adversaries might have a different @UUID[.O8IesdQo8SQpIKbo]{Archetype} and therefore have different attributes and talents, but they would all share a common progression from their shared Hobgoblin Taxonomy.

Archetype.name: Archetype
Archetype.text:
Archetype defines the skills and combat style of an Adversary in Crucible. Each Archetype further defines a taxonomy to:

  • Refine scaling weights for @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.abilityScores000]{Abilities} (above and beyond those defined by the Taxonomy),

  • Define skill progression

  • Configure any automatic equipment

  • Provides a set of automatically attained @UUID[Compendium.crucible.rules.JournalEntry.characterMechani.JournalEntryPage.talents000000000]{Talents}

Example: Fighter Archetype

Hardened melee combatants expert at wielding one-handed weaponry, shield, and heavy armor.

The Fighter Archetype defines scaling weights such that emphasize faster progression of Strength and Toughness, normal progression of Presence and Dexterity, and slower progression of Wisdom and Intellect.

Furthermore, the Fighter Archetype provides the Martial Weapon Training, Bulwark, and Armored Efficiency talents.

Many different Adversaries will use the same Archetype. For example a Level 2 Bandit Fighter, a Level 4 Hobgoblin Fighter, and a Level 7 Hellguard all share the Fighter Archetype, but they each have different Taxonomies and therefore have different attributes and talents, but all share a common aspect of progression due to the Fighter Archetype.
